Normal schools, also known as teacher training schools, contributed to the development of more innovative and effective teaching practices in several ways:

1. Standardization of Teacher Education: Normal schools developed a standardized curriculum for teacher education across the United States. This curriculum emphasized the importance of pedagogy, subject matter knowledge, and classroom management. This standardization helped to ensure that all teachers had a solid foundation in the fundamentals of teaching, which set the stage for more innovative and effective teaching practices.

2. Practical Experience: Normal schools provided opportunities for pre-service teachers to observe experienced teachers in action in real classrooms. These observations, combined with the practical classroom experience that pre-service teachers received while student teaching, helped them to develop a repertoire of effective teaching strategies.

3. Emphasis on Child-centered Teaching: Normal schools emphasized the importance of student-centered teaching, which focuses on meeting the individual needs of each student. This approach involved a shift away from traditional teacher-centered instruction, where the teacher was the focus of the classroom.

4. On-going Professional Development: Normal schools emphasized the importance of on-going professional development for teachers. This emphasis on professional development helped to ensure that teachers were continually learning and growing in their practice, which resulted in more effective teaching over time.

The legacy of Normal schools can still be felt in the profession today, as many of the teaching practices developed during this time are still in use. These practices include student-centered teaching, the importance of pedagogy, and a focus on on-going professional development.
